awd_titl_txt: The Multisensory Training Benefit for Speech and Speaker Perception
awd_abstract_narration:
When listening to someone in a noisy environment, you can better understand what they say when you look at their face while they talk.  Providing audiovisual information about speech, not just audio information alone, has also been shown to help infants develop language. In some cases, using audiovisual information to train speech perception helps adults learn a second language, helps aphasic patients produce more fluent speech, and improves perception of heard speech by listeners with hearing impairments. This last group is of particular interest because roughly a third of U.S. adults have some degree of hearing impairment.

While this audiovisual training advantage is well established, it is unclear how exactly the effect works. Research will be conducted to determine the principles behind the effect, how and why it works, and in what circumstances. The investigators also explore why audiovisual training typically does not help hearing-impaired individuals who received cochlear implants after early childhood. One possibility is that their years of experience before receiving the cochlear implant required a heavy reliance on lip reading, leaving them over-reliant on information from the talker during audiovisual training. 

The specific issues examined are rooted in theories of multisensory learning. These issues include: a) whether simultaneous auditory and visual speech is necessary for the training advantage to occur; b) to what degree the advantage generalizes across different talkers for a given listener; and c) whether the use of other sensory channels, in this case audio and touch, results in a similar training advantage. Parallel experiments will be carried out with both normal-hearing individuals and individuals who received cochlear implants after early childhood. The research should not only improve speech perception training regimes for individuals in this clinical population but should also improve our understanding of typical speech and talker perception. More generally, the research should inform our understanding of perceptual learning and plasticity, as well as multisensory integration.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA AT RIVERSIDE

por.por_cntn:
Roughly a third of U.S. adults have some hearing impairment. While hearing aids are helpful to many, some impairments require more treatment. In some cases, training can help listeners better understand speech. Research shows that listeners can improve their perception of heard speech if they are first trained to hear the speech while looking at a talking face. This audiovisual training advantage has also been shown to help infants develop language; adults learn a second language; and aphasic patients produce more fluent speech.

While the audiovisual training advantage is well established, it is unclear how exactly the effect works. The funded research has been conducted to determine the principles behind the effect. The practical goal of the research has been to learn ways of improving audiovisual training methods especially for individuals who have received cochlear implants after early childhood. It is thought that because of their years of pre-implant experience relying on lipreading, these individuals over-rely on seeing the talker during training.

The specific questions examined by this research have been based on prominent theories of multisensory learning. These questions include: a) whether simultaneous auditory and visual speech is necessary for the training advantage; b) the degree to which the advantage generalizes across different talkers; c) whether other sensory channels can be used for the training advantage.  Regarding this last question, an established technique of perceiving speech by touching the face of a talker has been tested as an alternative means to induce the training advantage.

This research should not only help individuals in this clinical population, but should also  improve our understanding of speech and talker perception. More generally, the research should help our understanding of perceptual learning and plasticity, as well as multisensory  integration.

 

 


Last Modified: 07/12/2022
Modified by: Lawrence D Rosenblum
